chapter.p: 1And the word of Yahweh cameLiterally “was” to me, saying,Literally “to say” 2“And you, son of man,Or “mortal,” or “son of humankind” raise a lament against Tyre. 3And you must say to Tyre, the one who sits at the entrance of the sea as the merchant of the peoples to the many coastlands, ‘Thus says the Lord Yahweh:

ul.li1: Tyre, you yourself saidLiterally “you you said”
ul.li2: “I am perfect in beauty!”Literally “of beauty”
ul.li1: 4In the heart of the seas are your boundaries;
ul.li2: your builders perfected your beauty.
ul.li1: 5They built with pine trees from Senir
ul.li2: all of your boards for you;
ul.li1: they took cedars from Lebanon
ul.li2: to make a sailing mast for you.Literally “on you”
ul.li1: 6They made your oars
ul.li2: with oaks from Bashan;
ul.li1: your deck they made with inlaid ivory,
ul.li2: with cypress trees from the coastlands of Cyprus.According to the reading tradition (Qere)
ul.li1: 7Your sail was fine linen with colorful weaving from Egypt
ul.li2: to serve as a banner for you;Literally “to be for you as a banner”
ul.li1: blue and purple cloth from the coastlands of CyprusOr “Elishah”
ul.li2: was your awning.
ul.li1: 8The inhabitants of Sidon and Arvan
ul.li2: were your rowers;
ul.li1: your skilled men,Literally “wise men” O Tyre, were from your own people,Literally “in you”
ul.li2: and they were your seamen.
ul.li1: 9The elders of Gebal and its skilled menLiterally “wise men” were among youLiterally “in you”
ul.li2: as the repairers of the seam of your boat;
ul.li1: all of the ships of the sea and their mariners were among youLiterally “in you”
ul.li2: to barter your wares.
ul.li1: 10Persia and Lud and Put
ul.li2: were among your soldiers;Literally “in your army as the men of war your”
ul.li1: small shield and helmet hung among youLiterally “in you”
ul.li2: and gave to you your adornment.
ul.li1: 11The peopleOr “children,” or “sons” of Arvan and Helech
ul.li2: were on your walls all around,
ul.li1: and Gammadites
ul.li2: were in your towers.
ul.li1: They hung their quiversOr “shields” (cf. NJPS; NIV) on your walls all around;
ul.li2: they perfected your beauty.

chapter.p: 12“ ‘Tarshish was your trader; from the abundance of all of their wealth, with silver, iron, tin, and lead they exchanged for your merchandise. 13Javan, Tubal, and Meshech were your traders; in exchange for peopleOr “for a human person/soul” and an object of bronze they gave you your wares. 14From Beth Togarmah they exchanged horses and war horses and mules for your wares. 15The peopleOr “children” of Dedan were trading with you, many coastlands composed the region of your influence;Literally “hand” they brought back horns of ivory and ebony as your payment. 16EdomReading Edom for Aram was trading with you because of the abundance of your products, trading with malachite, purple wool yarn and colorful weaving, and fine white fabric and black corals and rubies; all these they exchange for your merchandise. 17Judah and the land of Israel were trading with you with wheat from Minnith and millet and honey and olive oil and balm; all these they gave for your wares. 18Damascus was trading with you because ofLiterally “for” the abundance of your products, because of the abundance of all of your wealth, trading with the wine of Helbon and white wool. 19Vedan and Javan from Uzal, they exchanged wrought iron, cinnamon,Or “cassia” and reed spice for your merchandise; all this was for your wares. 20Dedan was trading with you, with garments of woven material for riding. 21Arabia and all of the leaders of Kedar were your customers;Literally “traders of your hand” with young rams and adult rams and goats they were trading with them with you. 22The traders of Sheba and Raamah were trading with you, with the finest of every spice and with every precious stone and gold; they exchanged all these for your merchandise. 23Haran and Canneh and Eden, the traders of Sheba, Assyria, and Kilmad were trading with you. 24They were trading with you in finery, in mantles of blue cloth and colorful embroidered work and with rugs of variegated cloth in twisted cords and knotted tightly; these were among your merchandise.Literally “in your trading/marketplace” (cf. NET) 25The ships of Tarshish were carrying for you your wares, and you were filled, and you became very heavy in the heart of the seas.

ul.li1: 26“ ‘Into many waters
ul.li2: the rowers brought you;
ul.li1: but the east windLiterally “the wind of the east” wrecked you
ul.li2: in the heart of the seas.
ul.li1: 27Your wealth and your merchandise, your wares,
ul.li2: your mariners, and your seamen,
ul.li1: your shipwrightsLiterally “the repairers/strengtheners of your seams” and the barterers of your wares
ul.li2: and all of your soldiersLiterally “the men of your war” who are in you,
ul.li1: alongHebrew “and” with all of your crew who are in the midst of you,
ul.li2: they will fall in the heart of the seas on the day of your downfall.
ul.li1: 28At the sound of the shoutOr “cry” of your seamen,
ul.li2: the pasturelands will shake.
ul.li1: 29And they will go down from their ships,
ul.li2: all of those holding an oar,
ul.li1: mariners, all of the seamen of the sea
ul.li2: will stand on the land,
ul.li1: 30and they will lamentHebrew “lamented” over you with their voice,
ul.li2: and they will cry outHebrew “cried out” bitterly,
ul.li1: and they will throwHebrew “threw” dust on their heads,
ul.li2: and they will rollHebrew “rolled” in the dust.
ul.li1: 31They will shave themselves bald for your sake,Literally “And they made bald for you with baldness”
ul.li2: and they will dressHebrew “dressed” themselves in sackcloth,
ul.li1: and they will weepHebrew “wept” over you with a bitterness of soulOr “of their inner self”
ul.li2: and with bitter wailing.
ul.li1: 32And they will raiseHebrew “raised” over you with their wailing a lament,
ul.li2: and they will chantHebrew “chanted” a lament over you:
ul.li1: ‘Who is like Tyre,
ul.li2: like this destruction in the midst of the sea?’
ul.li1: 33When your merchandise went out from the seas,
ul.li2: you satisfied many peoples with the abundance of your wealth,
ul.li1: and by your wares
ul.li2: you made rich the kings of the world.
ul.li1: 34Now you are broken by seas
ul.li2: in the depths of waters;
ul.li1: your wares and all of your crew
ul.li2: in the midst of you have sunk.
ul.li1: 35All of the inhabitants of the coastlands
ul.li2: are appalled over you,
ul.li1: and their kings shudderLiterally “they have bristling hair” in horror;
ul.li2: they distort their faces!Literally “they are distorted as to faces”
ul.li1: 36The traders among the peoples hiss over you;
ul.li2: you have become a horror,
and you shall be no more forever!’ ”Literally “there is not you until eternity/endless ages” (cf. NRSV)
